user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of file_reader:
```c
static ssize_t
file_reader (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *buf, size_t max)
{
  FILE *file = (FILE *) cls;
  size_t bytes_read;

  /* 'fseek' may not support files larger 2GiB, depending on platform.
   * For production code, make sure that 'pos' has valid values, supported by
   * 'fseek', or use 'fseeko' or similar function. */
  if (0 != fseek (file, (long) pos, SEEK_SET))
    return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR;
  bytes_read = fread (buf, 1, max, file);
  if (0 == bytes_read)
    return (0 != ferror (file)) ? MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR :
           MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM;
  return (ssize_t) bytes_read;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no calls to any of the Standard Library string.h functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.). The function only uses fseek, fread and ferror; none are in the string.h set that this rule targets, so there are no direct Rule 21.17 issues to investigate in this snippet.

Notes (not flagged as suspicious under Rule 21.17):
- fread(buf, 1, max, file) reads up to max bytes into buf. Although this is not a string.h call and thus outside Rule 21.17, it is a potential source of out-of-bounds accesses if the caller passes a max larger than the actual size of buf. That is a general buffer-safety concern but not a Rule 21.17 violation.
- The cast (long) pos passed to fseek may truncate a large pos value on platforms where long is smaller than uint64_t; this is a portability/safety issue but not related to Rule 21.17.

Therefore, no code fragments are selected for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
